}} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=UK |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|UK|naval}} |Ship name=HMS ''Emperor of India'' |Ship namesake= |Ship ordered=1911 |Ship builder=[[Vickers]], |Ship struck=1931 |Ship reinstated= |Ship honours= |Ship fate= Sunk as target ship 1931, then raised and scrapped 1932 |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship captured= |Ship status= |Ship notes= |Ship badge= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class={{sclass-|Iron Duke|battleship}} |Ship type= |Ship displacement= 25,000 tons (normal)<br />29,500 tons (deep load) |Ship length= {{convert|622|ft|9|in|m|abbr=on|1}} |Ship beam= {{convert|90|ft|m|abbr=on|1}} |Ship draught= {{convert|32|ft|9|in|m|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion= 4 shaft [[Parsons Marine Steam Turbine Company|Parsons]] [[steam turbine]]s, driving four propellers<br />18 [[Babcock & Wilcox]] or [[Yarrow Shipbuilders|Yarrow]] boilers delivering 29,000 hp |Ship speed= {{convert|21.25|kn|km/h}} |Ship range= {{convert|14000|nmi|km|-1}} at {{convert|10|kn|km/h|1}} |Ship endurance= |Ship boats= |Ship capacity= |Ship troops= |Ship complement=925 |Ship armament=10 × [[BL 13.5 inch Mk V naval gun|BL {{convert|13.5|in|mm|sing=on|sigfig=4}} /45 Mk V guns]] in five twin turrets<br /> 12 × [[BL 6 inch Mk VII naval gun|BL {{convert|6|in|mm|sing=on|sigfig=4}} /45 Mk VII guns]] in single casemate mountings<br /> 2 × [[QF 3 inch 20 cwt|QF 3 inch 20 cwt anti-aircraft guns]]<br /> 4 × 21 inch submerged beam torpedo tubes |Ship armour= |Ship notes= }} |} '''HMS ''Emperor of India''''' was an {{sclass-|Iron Duke|battleship|2}} of the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Royal Navy]]. She was originally to have been named ''Delhi'' but was renamed just a month before launching after [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]], who was also [[Emperor of India]]. ''Emperor of India'' was laid down on 31 May 1912 at [[Barrow-in-Furness]] by [[Vickers]]. She was launched on 27 November 1913 and commissioned on 10 November 1914. Upon commissioning, ''Emperor of India'' joined the [[1st Battle Squadron (United Kingdom)|First Battle Squadron]] of the [[Grand Fleet]], based at [[Scapa Flow]]. ''Emperor of India'' later joined the [[4th Battle Squadron (United Kingdom)|Fourth Battle Squadron]] and was [[flagship]] of Rear-Admiral [[Alexander Ludovic Duff|A. L. Duff]]. King George V visited ''Emperor of India'' while inspecting the Fleet at Scapa in July 1915. She was in refit at [[Invergordon]] at the time of the [[Battle of Jutland]] in 1916. During Jutland, ''Emperor of India'' was replaced as flagship of Admiral Duff by {{HMS|Superb|1907|2}}. In 1917, ''Emperor of India'' replaced her sister ship {{HMS|Marlborough|1912|2}} as second flagship of the 1st Battle Squadron. ''Emperor of India'' was present at the surrender of the German [[High Seas Fleet]] in November 1918. She survived the cuts to the Royal Navy in the post-World War I climate and joined the [[British Mediterranean Fleet|Mediterranean Fleet]] in 1919. She was decommissioned in 1929 and was sunk as a [[target ship]] on 1 September 1931. She was raised the following year and sold for scrap on 6 February 1932. ==External links== {{Commons category|HMS Emperor of India}} {{Portal|Battleships}} * [http://www.maritimequest.com/warship_directory/great_britain/battleships/emperor_of_india/hms_emperor_of_india.htm Maritimequest HMS ''Emperor of India'' photo gallery] {{Iron Duke class battleship}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Emperor Of India (1913)}} [[Category:Iron Duke-class battleships]] [[Category:Vickers]] [[Category:Barrow-built ships]] [[Category:1913 ships]] [[Category:World War I battleships of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Royal Navy ship names]]
